intro: Anchusa pulla, commonly known as the lesser bugloss, is a flowering plant native to southern Europe and western Asia. It is a perennial herb that typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring basal rosettes of gray-green, woolly leaves. The plant produces spikes of blue or violet flowers from late spring to early summer, which attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Anchusa pulla thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, often found in rocky or gravelly habitats. Its ornamental value makes it a popular choice for gardens and naturalized areas.
